title: Opening Bell: NASDAQ Futures, Europe Leap As Upbeat Earnings Eclipse Dismal Data
text:
U.S. futures, European stocks climb as positive earnings eclipse weak economic data

Pound drops on uncertainty over Brexit deadline extension

WTI retreats despite surprise inventory drop

Key Events

Futures on the , and as well as European shares, inched steadily higher this morning as investors remained laser-focused on positive earnings reports, brushing aside less rosy economic data from both Europe and Asia—which set a somber tone for coming up later today.

The euro-area economy remained near contraction territory, with the region's shrinking for a ninth straight month. Japan’s PMI also underwhelmed, dropping the most in three years, while Australian numbers hit an all-time low.

STOXX 600 Daily Chart

The opened higher with every major benchmark in the green, creating a breakaway gap that included a potential upside breakout of a bullish pennant. However, similarly to what happened on the S&P 500, the retreat exposed resistance at the top of a massive broadening pattern—a formation that tends to develop at market tops amid a lack of market leadership.

The pan-European index then continued to climb with the help of bullish corporate results from markets heavyweights including (DE: ) and (DE: ). If it closes off its highs, it will have created a shooting star, underpinning tensions between the pennant bulls and the long-term top pattern since March.

GBP/USD Daily Chart

Meanwhile, the retreated as traders nervously awaited the E.U.'s decision on granting a Brexit deadline extension to the U.K. Technically, the currency trends within a potential falling flag, bullish after the 6% jump earlier in the month.

Earlier, Asian indices mostly advanced, with Hong Kong’s (+0.87%) outperforming on stimulus expectations, after the city's legislature formally abandoned its infamous extradition bill. China’s (-0.02%) was flat.

Global Financial Affairs

Yesterday, U.S. equities benefited from some upbeat company announcements, with the returning above the key 3,000.

Apple (NASDAQ: ) (+1.34%) set a new record, closing at the top of the session after Morgan Stanley raised the company's share target. Boeing (NYSE: ) (+1.04%) led the (0.17%) higher, after a dramatic increase in 737 Max plane’s output.

Tesla (NASDAQ: ) surged after hours as the company . (NASDAQ: ) beat revenue forecasts while (NASDAQ: ) exceeded both EPS and revenue expectations. (NYSE: ) and (NASDAQ: ) also beat forecasts, though the former posted weak guidance and the latter published disappointing revenue projections.

Manufacturing giant Caterpillar (NYSE: )’s missed on both metrics, citing economic uncertainty for a decline in costumer purchases. However, it was still rewarded by investors for its decision to cut production—which pushed the group's shares 1.23% higher, to a peak since July 23.

Conversely, the tumbled almost 2% on the continued downward effect of Texas Instruments's (NASDAQ: ) reduced fourth-quarter forecast.

Overall, investors are grappling with mainly positive earnings on the one hand and weakening economic data, compounded by some gloomy corporate warnings, on the other.

WTI Daily Chart

In commodities, gave up gains that had been sparked by an in crude inventories on Wednesday.

Up Ahead

{erl-6435||Amazon.com}} (NASDAQ: ) reports after market close on Thursday, with analysts expecting that higher costs in the short term.

The U.S. is coming up at 9:30am ET.

Market Moves

Stocks

The U.K.’s gained 0.2%.

The ticked 0.4% higher.

The climbed 0.3%.

Currencies

The was little changed.

The advanced 0.1% to $1.1137.

The climbed 0.2% to $1.2932.

The was little changed at 108.65 per dollar.

Bonds

The yield on 10-year Treasurys fell two basis points to 1.75%.

Germany’s yield slid one basis point to -0.40%.

Britain’s yield declined one basis point to 0.679%.

Commodities
